user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemTake:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemTake(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_mutex_internal_record_t *mutex;
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    int32                       return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        mutex = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_mutex_table, token);

        return_code = OS_MutSemTake_Impl(&token);
        if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
        {
            /* Always set the owner if OS_MutSemTake_Impl() returned success */
            mutex->last_owner = OS_TaskGetId();
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_MutSemTake:
typedef struct
{
    char      obj_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t last_owner;
} OS_mutex_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_mutex_internal_record_t OS_mutex_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
mutex->last_owner = OS_TaskGetId();
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The pointer mutex is used to modify the object (assigning to mutex->last_owner), so it must point to a modifiable (non-const) type. Rule 8.13 suggests adding const when the pointed-to data is not modified; here the data is intentionally modified, so making the pointer or the pointed-to type const would be incorrect.
